 I wouldn't actually support "locking them up", it was meant facetiously. I am not against them expressing their opinions either, as it is their right as Americans to do so. I find censorship, in most cases, to be destructive to both individual rights and the common good.
 
 In all seriousness however, I do believe that network news presents an overall problem for America. I strongly believe that network news has vastly contributed to the partisanship that has gripped our nation. Too many people in our country have grown content with simply listening to one side of the story, and again, thanks to the spin doctors who bloviate continuously, people have grown comfortable with allowing others to do their thinking for them. It is often much more difficult to solve a problem when you only have half the equation. Many Americans are too lazy to investigate matters for themselves, and consequently they are ill informed about the issues. Sadly, many of these same people vote. If our country required a basic political knowledge test prior to voting, how many people do you think would have voted in '08? I would be willing to be we would have eliminated at least 25% of those who did. I find it very disheartening when I see people holding signs that say "keep you government hands off my medicare", or when I hear people being interviewed for the Howard Stern show saying that 'Palin was a great choice to be Obama's running mate'. 
 
 It's great that we have the right to vote for our leaders, but that right comes with the great responsibility of being informed and educated.
